Title: How to prove this identity $\pi=\sum\limits_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\frac{\sin(k)}{k}\right)^{2}\;$?
Content:
How to prove this identity? $$\pi=\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty}\left(\dfrac{\sin(k)}{k}\right)^{2}\;$$
I found the above interesting identity in the book $\bf \pi$ Unleashed . Does anyone knows how to prove it? Thanks.
AcceptedAnswer: Find a function whose Fourier coefficients are $\sin{k}/k$.  Then evaluate the integral of the square of that function. To wit, let $$f(x) = \begin{cases} \pi & |x|<1\\0&|x|>1 \end{cases}$$ Then, if $$f(x) = \sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} c_k e^{i k x}$$ then $$c_k = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} dx \: f(x) e^{i k x} = \frac{\sin{k}}{k}$$ By Parseval's Theorem : $$\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin^2{k}}{k^2} = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-\pi}^{\pi} dx \: |f(x)|^2 = \frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{-1}^{1} dx \: \pi^2 = \pi $$ ADDENDUM This result is easily generalizable to $$\sum_{k=-\infty}^{\infty} \frac{\sin^2{a k}}{k^2} = \pi\, a$$ where $a \in[0,\pi)$, using the function $$f(x) = \begin{cases} \pi & |x|<a\\0&|x|>a \end{cases}$$
